channel.title: Health on VitaminDWiki
channel.description: Recent content in Health on VitaminDWiki

item.title: Prescription drugs are the 3rd cause of all US deaths, 4th cause of deaths in hospital
item.description:
Prescription Drugs Are the Leading Cause of Death

Brownstone

  • “37,309 drug deaths were reported to the FDA in 2006 and%%% 123,927 ten years later, which is 3.3 times as many”

  • “Depression drugs kill many people, mainly among the elderly, because they can cause orthostatic hypotension, sedation, confusion, and dizziness. The drugs double the risk of falls and hip fractures in a dose-dependent manner,8,9 and within one year after a hip fracture, about one-fifth of the patients will have died. As elderly people often fall anyway, it is not possible to know if such deaths are drug deaths.”

item.title: Early-Onset diseases and Vitamin D - several studies
item.description:
Candidate causes include:

||Low vitamin D| (which can be fought by Vitamin D)

Microplastics now causing problems in most life forms - many studies|Microplastics| (which can be fought by Vitamin D)

Ultra-processed foods associated with worse health and lower Vitamin D - several studies|Ultra-processed foods |(which can be fought by Vitamin D)

item.title: US IRS now favors drugs over wellness
item.description:
IRS Cracks Down on Deductions for Healthy Food, Exercise as Childhood Chronic Disease Epidemic Explodes

ChildrenHealthDefense

Includes a link to the 40 minute podcast

  • “March 6 IRS “reminder” warning that people who use health savings accounts (HSAs) and flexible spending accounts (FSAs) will no longer be able to deduct “nutrition, wellness and general health” expenses — even if a doctor provides a note recommending them — unless they are “related to a targeted diagnosis-specific activity or treatment.””

item.title: Ultra-processed foods associated with worse health and lower Vitamin D - several studies
item.description:
Ultra-processed food and adverse health outcomes – BMJ meta-analysis Jan 2024

Credible increased risk of 9 health problems (a subset of table)

Ultra-processed food exposure and adverse health outcomes: umbrella review of epidemiological meta-analyses

BMJ 2024;384:e077310 http://dx.doi.org/10.1136/bmj-2023-077310

Melissa M Lane,1 Elizabeth Gamage,1 Shutong Du,2,3 Deborah N Ashtree,1 Amelia J McGuinness,1 Sarah Gauci,1,4 Phillip Baker,5 Mark Lawrence,6 Casey M Rebholz,2,3 Bernard Srour,7 Mathilde Touvier,7 Felice N Jacka,1,8,9 Adrienne O’Neil,1 Toby Segasby,10 Wolfgang Marx1

item.title: Which health problems take more than 10 years to develop - Chat-GPT
item.description:
Chat-GPT answer

Several health conditions can take more than 10 years to develop, often due to a combination of genetic, lifestyle, and environmental factors. Here’s a list of some notable conditions that typically have a long development period:

  1. Cardiovascular Diseases : Heart disease, including atherosclerosis (hardening and narrowing of the arteries), can develop over many years. Lifestyle factors like diet, exercise, and smoking play a significant role in their progression.

item.title: 16 Longevity books compared in a video
item.description:
Peter Attia’s Longevity Book Outlive: The BEST or WORST longevity book?

YouTube 35 minutes

Books

  1. Outlive: The Science and Art of Longevity by Peter Attia

  2. The Longevity Project: Surprising Discoveries for Health and Long Life from the Landmark Eight-Decade Study

  3. The Longevity Diet by Valter Longo

  4. The Path to Longevity: The Secrets to Living a Long, Happy, Healthy Life by Luigi Fontana

  5. How Not to Age: The Scientific Approach to Getting Healthier as You Get Older by Michael Greger

item.title: Chronic Health Conditions: 27% of Americans have more than 1 of the top 10 - CDC 2018
item.description:
Prevalence of Multiple Chronic Conditions Among US Adults, 2018

CDC Sept 2020

Download the PDF from VitaminDWiki

Top 10 chronic conditions (before COVID and Long-COVID)

  1. arthritis,

  2. cancer,

  3. chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD),

  4. coronary heart disease,

  5. current asthma,

  6. diabetes,

  7. hepatitis,

  8. hypertension,

  9. stroke, and

  10. weak or failing kidney

Health Problems and D| All of the above are prevented/treated by Vitamin D

item.title: Down syndrome people have even lower D levels if have additional Vitamin D diseases
item.description:
Hypovitaminosis D in persons with Down syndrome and autism spectrum disorder

J Neurodev Disord . 2023 Oct 25;15(1):35. doi: 10.1186/s11689-023-09503-y.

Natalie K Boyd 1, Julia Nguyen 2, Mellad M Khoshnood 1, Timothy Jiang 1, Lina Nguyen 1, Lorena Mendez 1, Noemi A Spinazzi 3, Melanie A Manning 4, Michael S Rafii 5 6, Jonathan D Santoro 7 8

Background: Plasma levels of vitamin D have been reported to be low in persons with Down syndrome (DS) and existing data is limited to small and homogenous cohorts. This is of particular importance in persons with DS given the high rates of autoimmune disease in this population and the known relationship between vitamin D and immune function. This study sought to investigate vitamin D status in a multi-center cohort of individuals with DS and compare them to individuals with autism spectrum disorder (ASD) and neurotypical (NT) controls.

item.title: Doctors are incentivised to prescribe medicines, not improve health
item.description:
How PCPs are penalized for positive outcomes from lifestyle change

MD Edge

One example: Dr. reduced diabetes by lifestyle changes

  • However, the CMS 5-Star Rating System assigned the primary care physician a grade of C rather than A, which put the physician›s 5-star rating at risk. Why? Because the system bases its score largely on medication compliance . The physician was penalized despite achieving the optimal health outcome, and at a lower cost than with medication. "

Medicare incentivizes disease management, not disease reversal

item.title: Live 24 years longer if have 8 habits (survey of 700,000 veterans)
item.description:
The eight habits researchers recommend to lengthen life expectancy

URL

According to the results, men who practised all eight habits by age 40 would be predicted to live an average of 24 years longer than men with none of these habits. %%%For women, having all eight healthy lifestyle factors in middle age was associated with a predicted 21 additional years of life compared to women with none of these habits.

item.title: US Healthcare spending to consume 20% of GDP by 2028
item.description:
Modern HealthCare March 2022

VitaminDWiki - Cost savings with Vitamin D contains:

It appears that Vitamin D can cut the cost of healthcare in half

Hope to have a demonstration with 5,000 people in 2024 getting 50,0000 IU weekly

--------

---

#### [Modern HealthCare](https://www.modernhealthcare.com/healthcare-economics/healthcare-spending-consume-20-gdp-2028#:~:text=As%20a%20result%2C%20the%20healthcare,which%20was%2017.7%25%20of%20GDP.) March 2022

---

#### VitaminDWiki - [Cost savings with Vitamin D](/categories/cost-savings-with-vitamin-d) contains:

---

#### It appears that Vitamin D can cut the cost of healthcare in half

 **Hope to have a demonstration with 5,000 people in 2024 getting 50,0000 IU weekly**

!!!!It appears that Vitamin D can cut the cost of healthcare in half
__Hope to have a demonstration with 5,000 people in 2024 getting 50,0000 IU weekly__

item.title: Rare diseases: 1 in 10 Americans (some are helped by Vitamin D) - 2023
item.description:
There are more than 10,000 known rare diseases.

Approximately 80% of rare diseases are estimated to have a genetic origin.

Of those, 70% start in childhood. (56% of rare diseases start in childhood)

  • “In the United States, about half of the people with a rare disease are children. Many of these diseases are chronic and worsen over time.”

The US defines incidence of a “rare disease” as being 1 in every 1,500 people
